newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS - Dividend arbitrage deal struck in BP.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dividend arbitrage deal struck in BP.

text.p: A dividend arbitrage strategy in British Petroleum was the biggest UK stock options deal on Friday in a quiet market, dealers said.
The strategy locks in a profit irrespective of how the underlying stock and options behave after the deal has been struck.
The deal was to buy 2,000 April 850 puts at 166p as well as two million shares at 690.15p making a net debit of 856.15p.
The shares will go ex-dividend by 6.5625p gross (5.25p net of basic tax) on Monday so the puts can then be exercised to sell the shares without losing the dividend.
The net credit for this will be 856.5625p so a risk free profit of 0.4125p per share, or 8,250 stg overall can be achieved.
By 1330 GMT, BP shares had fallen 5-1/2p to 689p.

Over in banking group Lloyds TSB, the main deal was the sale of 1,000 March 500 puts at 16p. The group announced full year pre-tax profits for 1996 at 2.51 billion stg, which were slightly ahead of analysts forecasts.
There was also some activity in British Telecommunications.
The main deal was a short strangle, in which 200 May 420 puts were sold at 8p as well as 200 May 460 calls at 13-1/2p. Further deals in the same options series were subsequently struck.
The deals will make a maximum profit at expiry if the shares stay between 420p and 460p. BT shares slipped 2-1/2p to 438-1/2p.
Elsewhere, in conglomerate Lonrho there was a buyer of 500 March 130 puts at 4-1/2p. Lonrho shares added 2p to 131p.
